title: Taal Volcano
meta_title: Taal Volcano — Eruption History, Height, Type & Facts | VolcanoAtlas
meta_description: Taal is a 311 m active caldera volcano in the Philippines. Explore its full eruption history from 1572 to 2025, hazard zones, current status, and visitor guide.

quick_answer.what: Taal is an active caldera volcano located within the 15 × 20 km Talisay (Taal) caldera on the island of Luzon in the Philippines, rising just 311 m (1,020 ft) above sea level on Volcano Island in Lake Taal.
quick_answer.status: Active — last erupted April 2024–2025. Continuously monitored by PHIVOLCS. Alert Level has fluctuated between 1 and 3 in recent years.
quick_answer.famous_for: One of the world's smallest but most dangerous active volcanoes. The prehistoric VEI 6 eruption (~3580 BCE) formed the massive Taal caldera, and the 1911 eruption killed over 1,300 people. The dramatic January 2020 eruption (VEI 4) forced the evacuation of nearly 500,000 residents.
quick_answer.danger_level: One of the IAVCEI 'Decade Volcanoes' — approximately 5–6 million people live within 30 km of Taal, making it one of the most hazardous volcanoes on Earth.

key_facts_box.tectonic_setting: Subduction zone — Philippine Sea Plate beneath Eurasian Plate / Continental crust (> 25 km)
key_facts_box.nearest_city: Tagaytay — 15 km north; Manila — 60 km north
key_facts_box.summit_crater: Main Crater lake ~1.2 km wide on Volcano Island
key_facts_box.monitoring_agency: Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology (PHIVOLCS)
key_facts_box.notable_feature: Volcano Island in Lake Taal, which itself sits inside the Taal caldera — a 'lake within a volcano within a lake within a volcano'

overview.content: Taal Volcano is an active caldera complex located on the island of Luzon in Batangas Province, the Philippines, approximately 60 km (37 mi) south of Manila. Despite a summit elevation of just 311 m (1,020 ft), Taal is one of the most active and dangerous volcanoes in the Philippines and in the entire Ring of Fire, with 40 recorded eruptions since ~3580 BCE and a maximum VEI of 6. The volcano's distinctive geography is unique in world volcanology: Volcano Island, the site of all historically observed eruptions, sits in the north-central part of Lake Taal, a 267 km² freshwater lake that fills the 15 × 20 km Talisay caldera — creating the famous 'island within a lake within an island' configuration, sometimes extended to 'a lake within a volcano within a lake within a volcano' because the Main Crater on Volcano Island itself contains a smaller crater lake. Taal was designated one of 16 'Decade Volcanoes' by the International Association of Volcanology and Chemistry of the Earth's Interior (IAVCEI) in 1991, owing to its explosive history, proximity to densely populated areas, and the extraordinary threat it poses to the roughly 5–6 million people living within 30 km. The January 12, 2020 phreatomagmatic eruption (VEI 4) generated a 14 km ash column, lightning-laced plumes, and base surges that forced the evacuation of nearly 500,000 people, serving as a dramatic reminder that Taal remains one of the world's most consequential volcanoes. Its 40 eruptions make it comparable in frequency to Mayon, while its caldera structure and lake setting draw comparisons to Krakatau and Pinatubo.

geology_and_formation.content: Taal's geological history spans at least several hundred thousand years, with the current caldera structure resulting from multiple catastrophic eruptions. The 15 × 20 km Talisay caldera was formed by at least four major ignimbrite-producing eruptions, the most recent being the VEI 6 event around 3580 BCE that deposited thick dacitic pyroclastic flows across the surrounding lowlands. Prior to caldera collapse, the ancestral Taal edifice may have risen to over 2,000 m (6,560 ft), comparable to other major Philippine stratovolcanoes. Lake Taal, which fills much of the caldera to a maximum depth of 160 m, has its surface just 3 m above sea level — one of the lowest volcanic lake elevations on Earth. Volcano Island, approximately 5 km (3 mi) across, is composed of coalescing small stratovolcanoes, tuff rings, and scoria cones built by post-caldera eruptions. Several additional eruptive centers lie submerged beneath Lake Taal. Taal sits along the Macolod Corridor, a zone of crustal thinning and extension within the broader subduction framework where the Philippine Sea Plate dives beneath the Eurasian Plate. This tectonic setting produces andesitic to basaltic andesitic magmas typical of arc volcanism, though the caldera-forming eruptions involved more evolved dacitic compositions. The interaction between magma and the abundant water from Lake Taal frequently drives phreatomagmatic eruptions — violently explosive events caused when hot magma encounters water, generating devastating base surges and pyroclastic density currents.

eruption_history_overview.content: Taal's eruptive record spans approximately 5,600 years, with 40 recorded eruptions (39 confirmed). The earliest documented event is the massive VEI 6 caldera-forming eruption around 3580 BCE. Historical records begin in 1572, coinciding with Spanish colonization of the Philippines, and document 39 eruptions through to 2025. Taal's eruption frequency is remarkable: the volcano has averaged roughly one eruption every 14 years over the historical period, with particularly active clusters in the 17th century (5 eruptions), the 18th century (9 eruptions), and the 20th century (11 eruptions). Five eruptions reached VEI 4 — in 1716, 1749, 1754, 1965, and 2020 — making Taal one of the most explosively powerful volcanoes in Southeast Asia. The interaction between magma and lake water has defined Taal's eruptive character: many eruptions are phreatomagmatic, producing lethal base surges that race across the lake surface at speeds exceeding 100 km/h, reaching lakeside communities within minutes.

subsections.title: The ~3580 BCE Caldera-Forming Eruption (VEI 6)
subsections.content: The most powerful known eruption in Taal's history occurred around 3580 BCE, producing massive dacitic pyroclastic flows and ignimbrites that contributed to the formation (or enlargement) of the Talisay caldera. This VEI 6 event was comparable in magnitude to the 1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo and ejected tens of cubic kilometers of material. The resulting caldera eventually filled with water to form the present-day Lake Taal. Deposits from this eruption have been identified across large areas of Batangas Province, and the event likely devastated any ecosystems and communities in the surrounding region.

subsections.title: The 1754 Eruption — Taal's Most Destructive Historical Event (VEI 4)
subsections.content: The eruption that began on May 15, 1754 was the longest and most devastating in Taal's recorded history, lasting approximately 7 months with multiple explosive phases. Violent phreatomagmatic explosions sent base surges racing across Lake Taal, destroying lakeside communities. Massive ashfall buried towns, collapsed roofs, and devastated agricultural land across Batangas. The eruption produced lava flows that extended the shoreline of Volcano Island and significantly altered the geography of the lake. The town of Taal, then the provincial capital, was so thoroughly devastated that it had to be relocated to its present site. Historical accounts describe darkness lasting days, rains of mud, and earthquakes felt as far as Manila. While precise casualty figures are uncertain, this eruption caused widespread death and displacement and remains Taal's most destructive historical event.

subsections.title: The 1911 Eruption — 1,335 Killed (VEI 3)
subsections.content: On January 27, 1911, Taal produced a violent phreatomagmatic eruption from the Main Crater that killed 1,335 people — the deadliest volcanic event in the Philippines until the 1991 Pinatubo eruption. The eruption generated a massive 'dark cloud' that was actually a devastating base surge — a ground-hugging current of superheated gas, steam, and rock fragments — that swept across Volcano Island and onto the shores of Lake Taal within minutes. The surge obliterated every structure on Volcano Island and killed all inhabitants who had not evacuated. Livestock, vegetation, and fish in the lake were destroyed. The eruption column rose to approximately 15 km. Despite its relatively modest VEI of 3, the lethality resulted from the phreatomagmatic interaction with lake water, which turned the eruption into a fast-moving lethal blast rather than a conventional ash column. This disaster catalyzed the establishment of the Philippine Commission on Volcanology, a forerunner to today's PHIVOLCS.

subsections.title: The 1965 Eruption — Lethal Base Surges (VEI 4)
subsections.content: The September 28, 1965 eruption from the southwest flank near Mount Tabaro was another devastating phreatomagmatic event. Base surges generated during the eruption crossed the 4 km distance over Lake Taal in minutes, killing approximately 200 people in lakeside communities. The eruption deposited a distinctive yellow-brown tuff ring around the vent and was instrumental in advancing the scientific understanding of base surges — a term borrowed from nuclear weapons testing that was first applied to volcanic eruptions based largely on studies of this event. The 1965 eruption continued intermittently until 1977, with additional phases in 1966 (VEI 3), 1967, 1968, 1969, 1970, 1976, and 1977, all centered near Mount Tabaro on the southwest flank.

subsections.title: The January 12, 2020 Eruption — Modern Crisis (VEI 4)
subsections.content: At approximately 2:30 PM local time on January 12, 2020, Taal erupted in a dramatic phreatomagmatic explosion from the Main Crater on Volcano Island. Within hours, the eruption column soared to 14–15 km (46,000–49,000 ft), illuminated by near-continuous volcanic lightning — producing spectacular and terrifying imagery broadcast worldwide. Base surges swept across Volcano Island, and heavy ashfall blanketed towns across Batangas and Cavite provinces. PHIVOLCS raised the alert level to 4 (out of 5), indicating imminent hazardous eruption. Nearly 500,000 people were evacuated from the 14 km danger zone, one of the largest volcanic evacuations in Philippine history. The eruption deposited between 3 and 9 million tonnes of ash, contaminated water supplies, destroyed crops, and collapsed roofs across the Taal Lake region. Ashfall reached Manila, forcing the closure of Ninoy Aquino International Airport. Remarkably, no direct fatalities from the eruption itself were reported, though 39 people died from eruption-related causes including stress, evacuation accidents, and illness. The eruption demonstrated both the volcano's destructive potential and the effectiveness of early warning and evacuation systems. Subsequent elevated activity through 2021–2022 and renewed eruption in 2024–2025 have kept Taal under intensive monitoring.

current_status_and_monitoring.content: Taal remains one of the most intensively monitored volcanoes in the Philippines and Southeast Asia. PHIVOLCS operates a comprehensive network around the volcano that includes broadband and short-period seismometers on and around Volcano Island, continuous GPS deformation monitoring stations, electronic tilt meters, and volcanic gas (SO₂) monitoring using both ground-based and satellite-based systems. Following the 2020 eruption, the monitoring network was significantly expanded. As of 2024–2025, Taal has been experiencing renewed eruptive activity with phreatic (steam-driven) explosions and elevated SO₂ emissions frequently exceeding 10,000 tonnes per day — among the highest rates recorded at any volcano globally. The alert level has fluctuated between Level 1 (low-level unrest) and Level 3 (magmatic unrest with increased tendency towards eruption). Volcanic smog ('vog') generated by Taal's massive sulfur dioxide output has been a persistent public health concern for communities downwind, particularly in Batangas and Cavite provinces. Scientists consider Taal to be in an extended period of unrest, and PHIVOLCS has repeatedly warned that a larger, more dangerous eruption remains possible.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content: Taal's hazard profile is shaped by three critical factors: its phreatomagmatic eruption style, the presence of Lake Taal, and the proximity of millions of people. Base surges — ground-hugging currents of hot gas, steam, and rock moving at 100–300 km/h — are the volcano's most lethal hazard, capable of crossing the 3–5 km lake surface in under a minute and reaching lakeside communities before any ground-based warning can be issued. Pyroclastic flows confined to Volcano Island can generate tsunamis in Lake Taal, threatening the 70+ km of populated shoreline. Ashfall is a widespread hazard: the 2020 eruption demonstrated that heavy ashfall can reach Manila, 60 km away, disrupting aviation, agriculture, and infrastructure. Volcanic smog from continuous SO₂ degassing affects air quality across a wide area, posing chronic health risks. Lahars (volcanic mudflows) threaten communities along drainage channels during the monsoon season. PHIVOLCS maintains a Permanent Danger Zone (PDZ) encompassing all of Volcano Island and a 7 km radius from the Main Crater. Despite warnings and evacuations following the 2020 eruption, informal resettlement has occurred on Volcano Island. The broader Taal region is home to approximately 5–6 million people within 30 km, making any large eruption a potential humanitarian disaster on the scale of Pinatubo 1991.

geography_and_physical_description.content: Taal's physical landscape is among the most geographically distinctive of any volcano on Earth. The Talisay caldera measures approximately 15 × 20 km and is breached on the southwest side, where the Pansipit River drains Lake Taal to Balayan Bay. Lake Taal itself covers 267 km² with a maximum depth of 160 m and a surface elevation of just 3 m above sea level. Volcano Island, situated in the north-central portion of the lake, spans roughly 5 km across and rises to 311 m at its highest point. The Main Crater — the site of most recent eruptions — is approximately 1.2 km wide and contained a crater lake until the 2020 eruption, which largely drained it. The island's surface is scarred by dozens of craters, tuff cones, and fissures reflecting centuries of eruptive activity from multiple vents, including the historically active areas of Binintiang Malaki, Binintiang Munti, Mount Tabaro, and Calauit. The caldera walls, rising 300–600 m above the lake on the northern and eastern sides, provide panoramic viewpoints from the city of Tagaytay along the northern rim. The surrounding caldera slopes support extensive agriculture, particularly coffee, coconut, and pineapple cultivation in the fertile volcanic soils.

climate_and_global_impact.content: Taal's eruptions have generally been regional rather than global in their atmospheric impact. Even the VEI 6 caldera-forming eruption around 3580 BCE likely had more localized consequences than comparable events at higher elevations because Taal's low summit elevation (311 m) means eruption columns must punch through more atmosphere to reach the stratosphere. However, the 2020 VEI 4 eruption injected sulfur dioxide into the upper troposphere, contributing to regional atmospheric haze. Taal's most significant ongoing atmospheric contribution is its extraordinary SO₂ degassing, which at peak levels has exceeded 20,000 tonnes per day — rivaling emissions from much larger eruptions at other volcanoes. This chronic degassing creates persistent volcanic smog ('vog') that affects air quality across southern Luzon, impacting agriculture, health, and visibility. In the context of global VEI comparisons, Taal's VEI 6 prehistoric eruption places it in the same class as the 1991 Pinatubo eruption, which caused measurable global cooling of approximately 0.5°C.

cultural_significance.content: Taal holds a profound place in Filipino culture and national consciousness. The Spanish colonial name 'Bombon' for the lake reflects its importance during the colonial era, when the original town of Taal (Batangas) was the region's administrative and commercial center before the devastating 1754 eruption forced its relocation. Taal Lake and its volcano are central to the identity of Batangas Province and are among the most photographed natural landmarks in the Philippines. The iconic view from Tagaytay Ridge — looking down into the caldera at Volcano Island and the Main Crater lake — is one of the country's most recognized vistas and a major domestic tourism draw. The tawilis (Sardinella tawilis), a freshwater sardine found exclusively in Lake Taal, is a cultural and culinary symbol of the region, though its population has been impacted by volcanic activity and environmental change. In indigenous Tagalog belief, Taal was associated with Bathala and other pre-colonial deities, and local legends describe the volcano's eruptions as expressions of divine anger. The 2020 eruption became a defining event for a generation of Filipinos, with images of the lightning-laced eruption column going viral globally and prompting a massive nationwide humanitarian response.

visiting_and_tourism.content: Taal is one of the Philippines' most popular natural tourist destinations, though access has been significantly restricted since the 2020 eruption. Prior to 2020, visitors could take a 20-minute boat ride from Talisay on the lake's northern shore to Volcano Island, then hike or ride horseback approximately 45 minutes to the Main Crater rim for views of the crater lake. This excursion was one of the most popular day trips from Manila, often combined with lunch at one of Tagaytay's ridge-top restaurants. Following the 2020 eruption, Volcano Island has been within the Permanent Danger Zone and is closed to tourism when alert levels are elevated. However, during periods of reduced activity (Alert Level 1), limited boat tours and crater hikes have been intermittently permitted. The Tagaytay Ridge viewpoint, accessible by car from Manila in approximately 1.5 hours, offers spectacular views of the entire caldera and remains open regardless of alert level. The Taal Volcano Protected Landscape, established in 1967, encompasses the caldera and surrounding areas. Visitors should always check current PHIVOLCS alert levels before planning any trip to the lake area.

nearby_volcanoes.content: Taal sits within the densely volcanic Luzon arc of the Philippines. Mayon, the country's most active stratovolcano and arguably the world's most perfectly shaped volcanic cone, rises 2,462 m in Albay Province, approximately 350 km southeast. Mount Pinatubo, whose cataclysmic VEI 6 eruption in 1991 was the second-largest eruption of the 20th century, lies 200 km to the northwest in Zambales. Closer to Taal, the Macolod Corridor — the tectonic zone in which Taal sits — includes several other volcanic features, including Mount Makiling (1,090 m), a dormant stratovolcano 30 km east whose geothermal system powers energy plants. The Bataan volcanic arc to the north includes Mount Natib and Mount Mariveles. Together, the Philippine volcanoes form one of the most active volcanic arcs in the Ring of Fire, with 23 historically active volcanoes monitored by PHIVOLCS.

etymology.content: The name 'Taal' derives from the Tagalog word 'taal,' meaning 'genuine,' 'pure,' or 'native.' The town of Taal in Batangas, which predates Spanish colonization, gave its name to both the lake and the volcano. During the Spanish colonial period, the lake was known as 'Bombon' or 'Bonbon.' The Tagalog language itself is sometimes called 'Taal' in reference to the town, reflecting the deep cultural roots of the name in the region.

facts: Taal is one of only a handful of volcanoes on Earth with a lake within a crater within an island within a lake within a caldera — a nested geographic structure unique in world volcanology.
The prehistoric VEI 6 eruption around 3580 BCE was in the same explosive magnitude class as the 1991 Mount Pinatubo eruption, which caused measurable global cooling.
Despite a summit elevation of just 311 m (1,020 ft), Taal is classified among the world's 16 Decade Volcanoes — the most dangerous volcanoes identified by the international scientific community.
The 1911 eruption killed 1,335 people, making it the deadliest eruption in Philippine history until Pinatubo in 1991, and led directly to the creation of the Philippine Commission on Volcanology.

The 1965 eruption of Taal was one of the first volcanic events where 'base surges' — a concept borrowed from nuclear weapons testing — were scientifically documented and described, advancing global understanding of volcanic hazards.
During the 2020 eruption, Taal's SO₂ emissions peaked at over 20,000 tonnes per day — among the highest volcanic degassing rates ever recorded anywhere in the world.
Lake Taal is home to the tawilis (Sardinella tawilis), the world's only exclusively freshwater sardine species, which is endemic to the lake and found nowhere else on Earth.
The 2020 eruption generated near-continuous volcanic lightning within the eruption column — a phenomenon rarely captured on camera at such scale — producing images that were broadcast worldwide.
Approximately 5–6 million people live within 30 km of Taal's Main Crater, making it one of the most densely populated volcanic hazard zones on the planet.
The 1754 eruption lasted approximately 7 months and was so devastating that the provincial capital had to be permanently relocated, reshaping the political geography of Batangas Province.
Taal has erupted 40 times since ~3580 BCE, averaging roughly one eruption every 14 years during the historical period — a frequency that places it among the most active volcanoes in the Philippines.
The surface of Lake Taal sits just 3 m (10 ft) above sea level, making the caldera floor one of the lowest volcanic depression surfaces on Earth.

faqs.question: Is Taal Volcano still active?
faqs.answer: Yes, Taal Volcano is one of the most active volcanoes in the Philippines and in the world. Volcanologists classify it as 'active' based on its 40 recorded eruptions spanning approximately 5,600 years, most recently in 2024–2025. The volcano is continuously monitored by PHIVOLCS (Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology), which maintains a network of seismometers, GPS stations, and gas sensors around the caldera. Taal has been in a state of elevated unrest since the major VEI 4 eruption of January 2020, with ongoing SO₂ degassing, seismic activity, and periodic phreatic explosions. Scientists consider further eruptions not just possible but probable. Taal is one of only 16 volcanoes worldwide designated as a 'Decade Volcano' by the international volcanological community.

faqs.question: When did Taal Volcano last erupt?
faqs.answer: Taal's most recent eruption began in April 2024 and continued into 2025, classified at VEI 2 with phreatic (steam-driven) explosions and elevated sulfur dioxide emissions. The most significant recent eruption occurred on January 12, 2020 (VEI 4), when a dramatic phreatomagmatic explosion generated a 14–15 km eruption column with spectacular volcanic lightning, forcing the evacuation of nearly 500,000 people. Between these events, Taal also erupted in July 2021 (VEI 1), November 2021–2022 (VEI 2), and October 2022 (VEI 1), indicating that the volcano has been in a persistent state of unrest for over five years.

faqs.question: Could Taal erupt again?
faqs.answer: Yes, Taal is virtually certain to erupt again. The volcano has produced 40 eruptions over approximately 5,600 years, averaging one eruption roughly every 14 years during the historical period. Since the VEI 4 eruption in January 2020, Taal has remained in a state of elevated unrest with continuous SO₂ degassing, frequent volcanic earthquakes, and multiple smaller eruptions. PHIVOLCS has repeatedly warned that a larger eruption remains possible. Historically, Taal's eruption clusters — such as the sequence from 1965 to 1977 — suggest that periods of heightened activity can persist for years or decades. The next significant eruption could range from a moderate phreatic event to a major phreatomagmatic explosion similar to the 1754, 1911, or 2020 events.

faqs.question: How many people have died from Taal eruptions?
faqs.answer: Taal has killed at least 1,500 people across its recorded history, making it one of the deadliest volcanoes in the Philippines. The 1911 eruption was the most lethal, killing 1,335 people when base surges swept across Volcano Island and the shores of Lake Taal. The 1965 eruption killed approximately 200 people in lakeside communities. The 1754 eruption caused hundreds of deaths, though precise figures are uncertain due to incomplete colonial records. The 2020 VEI 4 eruption, thanks to modern monitoring and the massive evacuation of nearly 500,000 people, resulted in 39 indirect deaths from evacuation-related causes rather than direct volcanic impacts.

faqs.question: How tall is Taal Volcano?
faqs.answer: Taal Volcano's highest point on Volcano Island stands at just 311 m (1,020 ft) above sea level, making it one of the lowest-elevation active volcanoes in the world. However, this figure is deceptive: the caldera rim (along Tagaytay Ridge to the north) rises to approximately 600–700 m, and the ancestral Taal edifice before the caldera-forming eruptions may have exceeded 2,000 m. The total relief from the deepest point of Lake Taal (160 m below the surface, or 157 m below sea level) to the island's summit is approximately 468 m. Taal's modest height belies its explosive power — the VEI 6 prehistoric eruption ranks among the most powerful known from any Philippine volcano.

faqs.question: What type of volcano is Taal?
faqs.answer: Taal is classified as a caldera volcano. A caldera is a large, basin-shaped volcanic depression formed when a volcano collapses into its emptied magma chamber after a massive eruption. Taal's Talisay caldera measures 15 × 20 km and was formed by at least four major ignimbrite-producing eruptions. Within this caldera lies Lake Taal, and within the lake sits Volcano Island — itself composed of multiple coalescing stratovolcanoes, tuff rings, and scoria cones. This nested structure makes Taal unusually complex. Its eruption style is predominantly phreatomagmatic, meaning explosions are driven by the violent interaction of hot magma with the abundant water from Lake Taal and the crater lake.

faqs.question: Why is Taal considered so dangerous?
faqs.answer: Taal is considered one of the world's most dangerous volcanoes due to four compounding factors. First, its phreatomagmatic eruption style produces base surges — ground-hugging currents of superheated gas and debris moving at 100–300 km/h — that can cross Lake Taal and reach populated shorelines within minutes, far too fast for ground-based evacuation. Second, approximately 5–6 million people live within 30 km of the volcano, with dense communities directly on the lake shores. Third, its eruption frequency (40 eruptions in ~5,600 years) means eruptions are not rare events but recurring threats. Fourth, the VEI 6 prehistoric eruption demonstrates Taal is capable of catastrophic caldera-forming events. These factors led to its designation as one of 16 IAVCEI Decade Volcanoes.

faqs.question: Can you visit Taal Volcano?
faqs.answer: Access to Taal depends on the current PHIVOLCS alert level. During periods of low unrest (Alert Level 1), limited boat tours from the Talisay shore to Volcano Island and guided hikes to the Main Crater rim have been intermittently available. However, since the 2020 eruption, Volcano Island has been within the Permanent Danger Zone and access has been frequently restricted. The Tagaytay Ridge viewpoint on the caldera's northern rim — accessible by car from Manila in about 1.5 hours — offers spectacular panoramic views of the entire caldera, Lake Taal, and Volcano Island, and remains accessible regardless of alert level. Always check current PHIVOLCS bulletins before visiting the Taal region.

faqs.question: What is the 'island within a lake within an island' at Taal?
faqs.answer: Taal's famous nested geography works as follows: Volcano Island sits in Lake Taal, which fills the Talisay caldera on the island of Luzon. On Volcano Island, the Main Crater contained its own crater lake (until it was largely drained by the 2020 eruption), and within that crater lake was a small island called Vulcan Point. This created the remarkable sequence: an island (Vulcan Point) within a lake (Main Crater lake) within an island (Volcano Island) within a lake (Lake Taal) within an island (Luzon). This nested structure, sometimes called 'the world's most complex volcanic geography,' is unique and has made Taal a subject of geographic curiosity worldwide.

faqs.question: What happened during the 2020 Taal eruption?
faqs.answer: On January 12, 2020, at approximately 2:30 PM local time, Taal erupted in a powerful phreatomagmatic explosion from the Main Crater on Volcano Island. The eruption column rose to 14–15 km (46,000–49,000 ft) and was illuminated by near-continuous volcanic lightning. Heavy ashfall blanketed Batangas and Cavite provinces, reaching Manila 60 km away and forcing the closure of Ninoy Aquino International Airport. PHIVOLCS raised the alert to Level 4, and nearly 500,000 people were evacuated. The eruption was classified as VEI 4. While no direct deaths occurred from the eruption itself — a testament to the monitoring and evacuation effort — 39 people died from related causes. The event caused an estimated ₱3.4 billion (US$67 million) in agricultural damage alone.
